oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Oxen and handler
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: African American man reins in two yoked oxen in a field he is preparing to plant. The farmer would have used a single-blade manual plow to cut the field. A a group of well-dressed white women stand, sit in, and walk around a wagon.

Oxen often were used as heavy work animals in the 19th century South. They supplied much of the power associated with agriculture and loading and unloading cargo-laden steamboats. They were used to haul heavy loads, plow fields, and remove stumps and rocks.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Women; Cattle; Laborers; Carts & wagons; African Americans
